question: 4 (b)
sols_html:
Step 1. If v is an eigenvector for a matrix A for some eigenvalue \(\lambda\), then we can write

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle Av = \lambda v\end{aligned}\]

Step 2. Since we assume that the matrix A is invertible, we can multiply on the above equation by that inverse on the left on each side and obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle A^{-1}Av = A^{-1}\lambda v\end{aligned}\]

Which is equivalent to

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle v = \lambda A^{-1} v\end{aligned}\]

Step 3. We would now like to divide by \(\lambda\), but before we should check that this is allowed, i.e. that \(\lambda\) is not zero. Since A in invertible, Aw = 0 = 0(w) implies w = 0. Thus \(\lambda\) = 0 is not an eigenvalue for A and we can safely bring \(\lambda\) to the LHS in the equation above. This yields

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \frac{1}{\lambda}v = A^{-1} v\end{aligned}\]

which would mean that v is an eigenvector for the eigenvalue 1/\(\lambda\) of the inverse of the matrix A. So we can conclude that the statement is true.
